http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: The two-semester Oral Communication course will provide students with an understanding of the dynamics of effective communication when speaking, listening, and responding. Students will express ideas and present information in a variety of communication tasks including small group discussion, democratic decision-making, formal and informal presentations, oral interpretation of literature, and argumentation. Students will develop basic communication competencies including ethical practices in communication; recognition of communication barriers; and effective use of interpersonal communication, listening, verbal and nonverbal messages, and use of digital media. Emphasis will be placed on research skills as students prepare for formal presentations and argumentation.
Communication Challenges
Students will evaluate various communication challenges.

Apply principles of ethical communication appropriate to context:
  • academic honesty
  • bias
  • communication responsibility
  • distorted evidence
  • logical fallacies
  • plagiarism
  • respect for diversity

Analyze the reduction of communication barriers:
  • alternate views
  • appropriate preparation
  • attitudinal
  • bias
  • communication apprehension
  • cultural
  • educational
  • environment
  • noise
  • nonverbal communication
  • perception
  • points of disagreement
  • proxemics / spatial
  • reticence
  • semantics
  • social
Identify advantages and disadvantages of electronically mediated and mass communication

Analyze the types and uses of mass media:
  • credibility and accuracy of sources
  • purpose of publication
  • recognizing bias
Communication Process
Students will demonstrate the communication process.

Analyze the effect of the communication channel on the sending and receiving of messages:
  • diverse perspectives
  • point of view

Examine intrapersonal communication:
  • goal setting
  • intrapersonal habits
  • Johari Window of self-awareness
  • Maslow's hierarchy of needs
  • perceptual process
  • self-concept
  • self-confidence
  • self-fulfilling prophecy
  • self-scripts

Demonstrate mutual respect in interpersonal communication:
  • aggressive
  • assertive
  • conflict-resolution strategies
  • passive
  • passive/aggressive
  • well-reasoned exchange of ideas
Demonstrate the ability to give and receive constructive criticism
Revise speech in response to critiques

Demonstrate appropriate critical, empathetic, appreciative, and reflective listening skills in formal and informal situations:
  • active listening behaviors
  • basic logical fallacies
  • false assumptions
  • loaded terms
  • note taking
  • points of agreement and disagreement
  • refutation process

Critique oral messages:
  • clarity
  • delivery
  • emphasis
  • evidence
  • paradigm
  • point of view
  • reasoning
  • relevance
  • strengths and weaknesses
  • word choice

Use context appropriate oral messages:
  • concrete expressions of thought
  • connotation vs. denotation
  • dialects
  • International Phonetic Alphabet
  • jargon
  • slang
  • standard English
  • text complexity
  • words and symbols
Speak while maintaining a formal style and objective tone

Demonstrate effective nonverbal communication skills:
  • attire
  • facial expressions
  • gestures (e.g., emphatic, descriptive, locative, transitional, signposting, dividing)
  • paralanguage
  • platform movement
  • proxemics/spatial communication

Adjust messages based on feedback:
  • audience adaptation
  • peer reviews
  • self-critique
Create strategic digital media presentations in a variety of communication tasks

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., textual, graphical, audio, visual, and interactive elements)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Collaborative Communication
Students will use effective forms of collaborative communication.
Participate in various communication groups

Demonstrate conversation skills in informal communication:
  • extenders
  • openers/ice breakers
  • reduction of negative conversation behaviors (e.g., domination, interruptions)
  • self-disclosure

Participate in a range of collaborative discussions:
  • justification of personal views
  • leadership
  • norms
  • preparation
  • questioning techniques
  • responses to diverse perspectives
  • roles
  • summarization
Engage in cooperative team-building

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., confidence, leadership styles, learning styles, learning teams, risk-taking, task teams)

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value:
Participate in democratic decision-making in a variety of contexts (e.g., classroom simulations, club meetings, civic meetings, co-curricular contests):
  • fundamentals and structure of parliamentary procedure (e.g., Mason's Manual of Legislative Procedure, Robert's Rules of Order, simplified chart of motions, Sturgis Standard Code of Parliamentary Law)
  • order of business
  • methods of framing motions
  • disposing of motions
  • consensus building
  • group decision-making process
Prepare an interview
Conduct an interview

Demonstrate appropriate business etiquette:
  • greetings
  • introductions
  • respect for diversity
  • technology
Public Communication
Students will use effective forms of public communication.
Present informal speeches adapting the message to a variety of contexts and tasks

Prepare formal speeches:
  • analysis of audience
  • citation of sources
  • creation of formal outline
  • identification of purpose
  • research from credible sources

Present information, findings, and supporting evidence clearly, concisely, and logically in informative and persuasive speeches and debate:
  • appropriateness (e.g., purpose, audience, task)
  • line of reasoning
  • oral style
  • organization
  • substance
  • Toulmin's Model

Apply debate fundamentals in a variety of formal and informal debates:
  • assume advocacy positions
  • establish a topic or resolution
  • support the topic/resolution with well-chosen, relevant, and sufficient facts
    • compose arguments to support claims
    • research arguments to support claims
    • present arguments to support claims
  • provide concluding statements that follow the selected debate format and support the arguments presented

Interpret oral readings from literary and informational texts using appropriate vocal expressions:
  • diction
  • elements of paralanguage (e.g., inflection, pause, pitch, rate, volume)
  • mood
Use figurative language

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: (e.g., allusion, antithesis, euphemism, imagery, metaphor, personification, simile)
